text: Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth.
And you may have noticed that my head is huge.

I’m testing my hypothesis that increasing
the size of our stick figures’ heads will

increase likes on our videos; let’s check
on the results of this rigorously controlled,
totally real study.
Ugh, no effect at all.

In science - not having the data support your
hypothesis - in other words, being wrong - is
called a “null result.”

And, honestly, being wrong can feel like failing,
as if I have nothing useful to report back
to the MinuteEarth team.

But, finding “nothing” - or no effect
- is still finding “something,” because
you have knowledge you didn’t have before.

Sometimes, this new information means that
what you thought was true isn’t.

For example, doctors have long assumed that
if a pregnant person with certain risk factors

moved around too much, the baby could be born
prematurely.

So doctors often recommended staying in bed,
sometimes for months at a time - even though
that comes with its own risks.

But over the years, study after study has
found that bedrest has no effect on premature

birth, clearly putting the rationale for bedrest
to rest.

And null results can also rule out futile
avenues of research.

For decades, physicists have been trying to
directly detect dark matter, the elusive stuff

that likely accounts for most of the matter
in our universe.

That elusiveness - not its color - is why
it’s called “dark” - I mean, we don’t
even know what size the particles are.

But we’re getting closer, thanks to null
results.

Some dark matter detectors are calibrated
to find particles of a certain size, so each

time they fail to detect anything, scientists
can eliminate that size as a possibility,

adjust their models and equipment, and narrow
the scope of their search.

It’s kind of like looking for a lost phone
- even if you don’t find it where you look,

you learn where it isn’t, letting you focus
your efforts elsewhere.

If and when scientists finally directly detect
dark matter, it will have been made possible

by the many previous experiments that found
“nothing.”

Null results don’t always have giant impacts
like unlocking the secrets of the universe
or saving pregnant people.

In fact, null results usually are pretty dull
results...sometimes you just learn that bigger

heads don’t increase likes, or, as a real
study found that eating chocolate doesn’t
make you smarter.

But being wrong is far from failing - after
all, you’re still learning something new,

and science is all about increasing our understanding
of the world around us.

So celebrate those null results - just don’t
get a big head about it.

This video was sponsored by Patrick Olson’s
aptly titled new album Music For Scientists.

The whole album is a fascinating exploration
of the relationship between art and science,

and the song “The Idea” focuses on the
process of testing ideas in science, being

wrong, and having to – as the lyrics state
– “rework the formula.”

In fact, we reworked the baseline of that
song to create the background music for the
video you just watched!

To hear the song - and see the music video
for it - click on the link in the description
and let them know that MinuteEarth sent you!
